awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Subtractive-waveguide based Display for Augmented Reality Smart Glasses using Spatial-temporal Multiplexed Single-CMOS Panels
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the realization of Augmented Reality (AR) displays for smart glasses that can show digital content in the full dynamic range, including the black color. The conventional optical components currently used in AR smart glasses cause the digital content to appear translucent and, hence, lack realism.  The proposed work is on developing a display technology that controls per-pixel transparency in the virtual image plane, virtual objects, and 3D holograms for black color. The blocking of light for black-colored parts in a hologram can show as realistic physical objects over the background reality. Using this approach, each display pixel can be made black, semi-transparent, or transparent at a user’s will, making visibility of digital content possible even in direct sun-lit environments.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes a holistic display solution for AR smart glasses that consists of three key elements: a spatially-multiplexed Total Internal Reflection–based subtractive-waveguide combiner; a single photo-reflective spatial light modulator (SLM) that is illuminated by two spatially-multiplexed illuminants; and a temporal multiplexing algorithm whereby the two spatially-multiplexed illuminants can be selectively modulated by the SLM during their dedicated sub-frame times. Since pixel-wise transparency control allows hard-edge occlusion, hence the proposed smart spatiotemporal multiplexed approach enables a single display that achieves pixel-wise hard-edge occlusion using only a single silicon display panel, thereby reducing cost and complexity while increasing see-through efficiency and battery life performance. These technological improvements are industry firsts and together allow for addressing a market need for AR devices for outdoor well-lit scenarios.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
To date Augmented Reality (AR) Displays cannot show Black pixels. This is due to the transparent nature of the combiner optic used. A combiner optic basically exhibits partial reflection and transmission hence simultaneously combining a reflected image with a transmitted image thereby overlaying the two. Therefore the Digital content appears translucent and does not appear solid. While this additive combiner approach works for Teleprompters in theaters with controlled lighting it is insufficient for AR smart glasses where the user’s background environment can vary from dark indoor spaces to outdoor sunlit situations with luminance reaching 10’s of kCd/m2. The additive combiner results in luminance competition between the background physical environment and the digital content thereby resulting in poor visual experience besides worsening battery life, size and weight of the AR headset. Despite about 15 years of development, no existing AR display can show sharp Black pixels even with the use of LCD dimmer laminated onto the smart glasses lens. The additional LCD dimmer has blurry pixels with poor contrast, and consumes >1Watt additional power hence even shorter battery life.  

Moreover, while the everyday consumer is used to enjoying high contrast and dynamic range visuals on smartphone screens, the visual experience on today’s smart glasses is muted because of a lack of contrast and the inability to show black pixels. For example, one cannot show Coke soda, dark chocolate, or Mickey Mouse on today’s smart glasses with acceptable fidelity due to the lack of Black pixels. These are everyday examples that the consumer is used to enjoying on their smartphone screens and if they can’t experience the same visuals on smart glasses, they don’t relate with them.

Furthermore, conventional waveguides such as geometric, or diffraction grating based or holographic polymer based, have low efficiency of the order of ~0.05% due to inefficient pupil expansion. In order to resolve these challenges, we proposed and built in SBIR Phase-I a subtractive display solution that utilizes Total Internal Reflection (TIR)–based combiner in a waveguide lens for enabling >50% efficiency, >90% high see-through transparency and 100:1 high contrast ratio simultaneously (see FIGS. 1-4). During this SBIR Phase-I project, we built our Alpha Pix™ technology using our catadioptric TIGR waveguide design which allows Pixel-wise local dimming to enable below features: 

  • Sharp Black pixels and can show shadows 

  • Reduced power consumption →  Longer battery life 

  • Increased visibility in bright environments 

There following 3 major parts of the R&D effort were carried out:

1. Optical design of a TIGR waveguide,

2. Optical design of imaging optics,

3. Prototype development of TIGR waveguide.

An optical design simulation for the catadioptric TIGR was conducted in ray tracing software-Zemax shown in the layout in FIGS. 1. In order to assemble the TIGR waveguide, a fabrication process was developed. All design, fabrication and assembly of the TIR-based Combiner prism were carried out internally. 

FIGS. 2 (a) shows the actual fabricated plastic prism; and (c) the mold machinery used for custom molded plastic prism. A manufacturing friendly material, PMMA was used, with a refractive index of 1.49. The TIGR3 waveguide has >90% transparency at up to 70degrees angle of incidence, similar to an AR coated eye glasses.

FIGS. 3(a) shows the assembled prototype TIGR waveguide in a lens form which was all carried out in-house. FIGS. 3(a) shows see-through view from the fully transparent TIGR waveguide lens at thetaTIR; and 3(b) seeing-through the fully reflective waveguide at theta>thetaTIR incidence angle. The optical throughput efficiency of the optical engine including the TIGR waveguide is ~51-60% for the Reality channel, Alpha.

As can be seen through various figures in this Phase-I Report, the emphasis in this Phase-I project was on quick turn design and prototyping of the subtractive TIGR waveguide and iteration on the design. The learnings from each of the prototype builds helped improve the consequential custom designed waveguide, the associated imaging lens and the full stack of catadioptric optical engine. The quick-turn iterative process resulted in step function improvements in terms of optical throughput efficiency of the waveguide, simplification of the optical stack, and cost reduction.

The Phase-I effort has successfully validated the technical feasibility of the subtractive waveguide. For commercial feasibility, the bench-top prototype will be showcased to potential OEM customers in 1-on-1 meetings and tradeshows. The feedback and learning from customer input will steer developing a custom built optics platform under SBIR Phase-II.

Besides making progress on this SBIR Phase-1 project, we have made tremendous development partnerships with relevant industry players such as Texas Instruments’ DLP Products, 3M, Colorlink, Nagase, and Kyoritsu. 

Since Cogni Trax’ technology improves content visibility and can selectively block specific areas of the user’s Physical environment, it can help improve the visual experience for people with albinism, specific bright regions that cause glare for the user, can be selectively dimmed down to improve the affected individual’s visual experience.
